title: 104_hr3298
content: The Act titled "Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council Act of 1996" emphasizes the importance of intergovernmental cooperation for sustainable development of resources in Voyageurs National Park. It aims to preserve, protect, and improve resources for the benefit of the people of the United States. The Act also focuses on enhancing coordination among all levels of government in the Voyageurs region. The Act titled "Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council Act of 1996" emphasizes intergovernmental cooperation for sustainable development in Voyageurs National Park. It introduces a new section, SEC. 306, to establish the Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council. The Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council (Council) is established with 11 members, including representatives from various Minnesota departments and organizations. The Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members, including representatives from St. Louis County, Koochiching County, State Senators, State Representatives, and a member of the Native American community representing the 1854 Treaty Authority. The Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members, including representatives from various entities. Members appointed for a four-year term can continue serving until a successor is appointed. Non-government members serve without pay but receive travel expenses. The Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council consists of 11 members who serve for four-year terms. A quorum of eight members is required for meetings, with a chairperson elected from among the members. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Secretary provides staff and technical assistance as needed. Meetings are called by the chairperson or a majority of members. The Council receives personnel, property, and services on a reimbursable basis to assist in its duties. The Secretary can accept personnel from the State of Minnesota and reimburse for their services. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Council. Guidelines for meetings include openness to the public and holding emergency meetings when necessary. The Council holds regular and emergency meetings where interested persons can present statements on agenda items. Public notice of meetings is published in local newspapers for wide publicity, and minutes are kept for record-keeping. The Council's meetings must include records of attendees, discussions, conclusions, and filed statements. The administrative record, minutes, and related documents are open to the public for inspection. Additionally, new information from State or Federal agencies can be considered at any time. The Council must consider new information from State or Federal agencies or the public before taking final action on management measures. The Council is responsible for preparing and submitting comprehensive draft amendments to the management plan in accordance with the Act. The Council is responsible for analyzing the economic and environmental costs and benefits of sustainable practices for Voyageurs National Park, conducting public hearings for input on plan amendments, preparing proposed revisions to the draft management plan, and reviewing local, State, and Federal actions. The Council is responsible for analyzing the economic and environmental impacts of sustainable practices for Voyageurs National Park, conducting public hearings for input on plan amendments, preparing proposed revisions to the draft management plan, and reviewing local, State, and Federal actions, plans, ordinances, regulations, laws, and land use decisions to assess their effect on the region's long-term sustainability. They are also required to submit periodic reports to the Secretary and conduct other necessary activities as specified in the Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided for carrying out these functions. SEC. 4. REVISION OF VOYAGEURS NATIONAL PARK MANAGEMENT PLAN. The management plan for Voyageurs National Park will be amended to include recreational opportunities such as boating, aircraft use, snowmobiling, hiking, and skiing on major lakes and bays within the park. The Secretary will review draft amendments submitted by the Voyageurs National Park Intergovernmental Council and public comments before implementation. The Secretary will review and may submit recommendations on draft amendments to the management plan. If the revised amendments are consistent with laws and in the public interest, the Secretary will adopt them. If not, a management plan board will make the amendments. The management plan board, appointed under subparagraph (B), consists of three members appointed by the Secretary and other entities. Members not employed by the Federal Government serve without pay while performing services. The management plan board, appointed by the Secretary, consists of three members who are allowed travel expenses. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the board. The board reviews and submits amendments to the management plan to the Secretary for revision. If the Secretary does not approve or disapprove revised amendments to the management plan within 95 days, the amendments cannot be implemented until the Secretary complies. If the Council does not submit revised amendments, the Secretary can make necessary changes and implement the plan. The management plan of the park can only be changed according to this section.
